channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Welfare reforms fair - Duncan Smith
item.description: Changes to the UK's welfare system are fair, Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan Smith insists, as some of the new measures come into effect.

item.title: S Korea pledge over North threats
item.description: South Korea promises a "strong response" to any North Korean aggression, amid high tensions after Pyongyang warned of entering a "state of war".

item.title: India rejects Novartis patent plea
item.description: India's top court rejects a plea by Swiss company Novartis to patent an updated version of cancer drug Glivec, a move hailed by campaigners for cheap drugs but condemned by the industry.

item.title: NHS changes come into force
item.description: Government reforms of the NHS in England are now in place, with NHS leaders warning of a tough year ahead.

item.title: Miliband quits after Di Canio hired
item.description: Ex-foreign secretary David Miliband resigns from the board of Sunderland FC because of new head coach Paolo Di Canio's "past political statements".

item.title: UK general warns of Afghan troop cut
item.description: Cutting British forces in Afghanistan too quickly could "endanger" progress at a critical time, the UK's top commander there warns.

item.title: Dissident groups 'outdo each other'
item.description: The Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, Matt Baggott, has said dissident republican groups are trying to outdo each other.

item.title: Tanker bomb attack at Iraq police HQ
item.description: A suicide attacker blows up a tanker lorry at the police HQ in the Iraqi city of Tikrit, killing at least seven people.

item.title: Teachers attack ‘rebranded’ sexism
item.description: Teachers are warning that young people are being damaged by an over-sexualised culture.

item.title: Mandela spends sixth day in hospital
item.description: Nelson Mandela spends a sixth day in hospital for pneumonia treatment, as South African doctors report his condition is improving further.

item.title: Private newspapers return to Burma
item.description: Private newspapers are published in Burma for the first time in almost 50 years, as the latest in a series of democratic reforms comes into effect.

item.title: Melt 'causes Antarctic sea ice rise'
item.description: A paradoxical phenomenon involving more melt water may explain the recent expansion of Antarctic sea ice, scientists tell Nature Geoscience journal.

item.title: Beatles album sells for $290,000
item.description: A signed copy of The Beatles' album Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band is bought at auction in the US for $290,500 (£191,000).

item.title: German flea circus hit by freeze
item.description: A flea circus in Germany has been scrambling to replace its performers after the entire troupe was wiped out by the freezing weather.

item.title: Murray sets sights higher on clay
item.description: Andy Murray says he can improve as he heads into the clay-court season ranked number two in the world.

item.title: Revival aimed at Irish National win
item.description: Brian O'Connell will aim to steer favourite Rich Revival to victory in Monday's Irish Grand National at Fairyhouse.

item.title: Di Canio is box office, says Wray
item.description: Former Swindon chairman Jeremy Wray tips Paolo Di Canio to be a success as Sunderland head coach.

item.title: Bolt begins season with 150m Rio win
item.description: Usain Bolt falls just short of his 150m world mark as he opens his season with victory on Copacabana beach in Rio.

item.title: Five reasons to watch MotoGP
item.description: With Valentino Rossi back at Yamaha, and Marc Marquez making the step up from Moto2, 2013 promises to be a classic MotoGP season.

item.title: UK financial regulation overhauled
item.description: The UK's banking regulator, the Financial Services Authority, is abolished and replaced with two successor organisations.

item.title: No house survey 'is false economy'
item.description: More families are shunning full building surveys so they can raise enough cash to buy a home, but this can lead to big repair bills later, surveyors say.

item.title: Mitchell complains to IPCC over Met
item.description: Ex-cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell launches a stinging attack on Scotland Yard over its inquiry into the 'plebgate' row.

item.title: ‘Pub quiz facts curriculum’ opposed
item.description: Teachers at the NUT conference attack the revised school curriculum in England as outdated and narrow.

item.title: Cystic fibrosis bug spread discovery
item.description: UK researchers have found that a dangerous infection which is becoming more common in people with cystic fibrosis can spread between patients.

item.title: Leeds heart surgery data 'wrong'
item.description: Children's heart surgery was wrongly suspended at Leeds General Infirmary because of "incomplete" information, a senior doctor says.

item.title: Teachers 'scared to use red card'
item.description: Some teachers are too scared to report misbehaving children in case they get in to trouble, a union conference has heard.

item.title: Warning of 'unqualified teachers'
item.description: Teaching unions are warning that children in England are increasingly being taught by unqualified staff.

item.title: Cat Video Festival returns to US
item.description: Over 10,000 people flocked to the first event held to celebrate internet videos of cats in America last year.

item.title: 'Petaflop' supercomputer shuts down
item.description: The first supercomputer to carry out 1,000 trillion calculations per second is switched off for good in the US state of New Mexico.

item.title: Cash shortage stretches to sea bed
item.description: The government admits going slowly on protecting wildlife in the seas because of the costs involved.

item.title: Met Office advice was 'not helpful'
item.description: The Met Office has admitted issuing "unhelpful" advice to government during last year's remarkable switch in weather patterns.

item.title: Ant and Dec top UK singles chart
item.description: TV hosts Ant and Dec are celebrating their first British number one single with a re-release of their 1994 hit Let's Get Ready to Rumble.

item.title: Fuller settles US X Factor case
item.description: British music mogul Simon Fuller settles his long-running copyright battle with TV network Fox over the US version of The X Factor.

item.title: The rise of chocolate purism
item.description: You can now buy 100% cocoa chocolate on the High Street, but does "real" chocolate have to be high in cocoa?

item.title: What's the secret to a happy marriage?
item.description: Adam Gopnik attempts to explain the secret to a happy marriage by reflecting on Charles Darwin, old comedy sketches and a Havanese dog.

item.title: Man hit by train after 'altercation'
item.description: A man from Surrey dies after being hit by a train following an altercation at Guildford railway station, police say.

item.title: Teacher dies on school ski trip
item.description: A teacher from a Nottinghamshire secondary school dies in a "freak accident" on a school skiing trip to Austria.

item.title: Local policing 'safe' under merger
item.description: Scotland's merger of its eight police forces into one will provide a more accountable local police service, the Scottish government claims.

item.title: Jobs lost as historic mill closes
item.description: Efforts to save Scotland's oldest continually-operating textile mill from closure fail, leading to the loss of 33 jobs.

item.title: Suspect device found in north Belfast
item.description: Police have found a suspect device on the Crumlin Road in north Belfast during a search on Monday morning.

item.title: North West police stations to close
item.description: Eglinton and Dungiven police stations in County Londonderry will formally close on Monday.

item.title: Devastation claim on benefit changes
item.description: Benefit changes will have a "destabilising" and "devastating impact", claims a Welsh government minister in a strongly-worded attack on the UK coalition.

item.title: Environment body's delivery pledge
item.description: The new merged body which will manage Wales' environment and natural resources starts work, promising to focus on maintaining the services that people rely on.

item.title: Bashir orders Sudan prisoner release
item.description: Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir says all political prisoners in the country will be released and that his government is committed to dialogue.

item.title: Tanzania collapse death toll rises
item.description: At least 30 bodies have now been retrieved from a building which collapsed in Tanzania's Dar es Salaam on Friday.

item.title: Bodies recovered in Tibet landslide
item.description: At least 36 bodies are recovered from a landslide in Tibet, state media report, after dozens of miners were buried on Friday.

item.title: Arrests in Indian politician murder
item.description: Police in the Indian capital Delhi arrest two men suspected of killing wealthy businessman and politician Deepak Bhardwaj.

item.title: Cyprus crisis: No Russian bailout
item.description: The Russian government says it will not compensate Russian savers who have lost money in the Cyprus banking crisis.

item.title: Greeks block Golden Dawn handout
item.description: Villagers on the Greek island of Thassos prevent the nationalist Golden Dawn party from handing out free food and other basic goods.

item.title: Foreign tourist raped on Rio minibus
item.description: Brazilian police say two men have been arrested, accused of raping and robbing a foreign tourist on a minibus in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Indigenous Colombians free soldiers
item.description: A Colombian indigenous group release three soldiers, who they had suspected of involvement in the killing of their leader.

item.title: Pope delivers Easter plea for peace
item.description: Pope Francis delivers a passionate plea for world peace - singling out "dear Syria" - in his first Easter Sunday speech since being elected.

item.title: Egypt satirist released on bail
item.description: Popular Egyptian TV satirist Bassem Youssef is released on bail after questioning by prosecutors over allegations that he insulted President Morsi.

item.title: Third US legal official shot dead
item.description: A district attorney in Texas is shot dead, becoming the third leading justice official to be killed in the US in a matter of weeks.

item.title: Deadly pileup in south-west Virginia
item.description: At least three people are killed and 15 injured in a pileup involving almost 100 vehicles in the US state of Virginia, police say.

item.title: Mozambique: Life in pictures
item.description: Ariadne Van Zandbergen explores this changing country

item.title: Your pictures: On the edge
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme On the edge

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 27 March

item.title: In pictures: Losing Ground
item.description: Communities in Cambodia fight for their right to land

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The health secretary has set out the government's response to the Stafford Hospital inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: Floods wreak havoc in Mauritius
item.description: A day of national mourning has been declared on the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean, where at least 11 people have died in severe floods.

item.title: VIDEO: Thief runs through glass door
item.description: A bag snatcher has managed to escape after running through the glass door of a Perth shopping centre.

item.title: VIDEO: Era of free press dawns in Burma
item.description: People in Burma will have a choice of daily newspapers for the first time in 50 years from 1 April.

item.title: VIDEO: Six-year old's ping pong prowess
item.description: Connor Green, six, has beaten people three times his age in table tennis matches despite only playing for just over a year.

item.title: VIDEO: Third US legal official shot dead
item.description: A district attorney has been shot dead in Texas, the third justice official to be killed in the US in recent weeks.

item.title: VIDEO: Football fans tackle homophobia
item.description: Brighton and Hove Albion supporters step up their campaign to tackle the issue of homophobic abuse.

item.title: VIDEO: Views on the Korean border crossing
item.description: Lucy Williamson reports from the highly guarded border between North and South Korea, as South Korea's president promises a swift military response to any provocation from the North.

item.title: VIDEO: Human parents for a baby gorilla
item.description: Human surrogate parents are raising a baby gorilla at a zoo in the US after she was rejected by her own mother.

item.title: How much gold is there in the world?
item.description: If you made a cube from all the world's gold, how big would it be?

item.title: The hidden prices rises of 1 April
item.description: The price of everything from post to plane rides goes up

item.title: Five ways the NHS is changing
item.description: Five ways the NHS in England is changing

item.title: Feeling unloved in Germany
item.description: The Nazi comparisons which offend Germans

item.title: VIDEO: New life after 20 years false imprisonment
item.description: Wrongly jailed for 20 years and moving on

item.title: The angels helping Indian start-ups
item.description: The angels helping Indian start-ups grow their businesses

item.title: Why small is now big in theatreland
item.description: A look at the National Theatre's small temporary stage

item.title: Gretna dream: Eloping to Scotland
item.description: The irregular marriage and other Scottish nuptial traditions
